title: CLARIAHChainingSearch: APlatformforCombinedExploitationof MultipleLinguisticResources
segmentation: I will present on Gloria Chaining search a platform for combined exploitation of multiple linguistic resources and my name is Peter Decker and I work at the Dutch language.
Institute in the Netherlands.

The idea of Korea chaining searches to make it possible to combine heterogeneous claren resources, research of different kinds, corpora, lexica, and treebanks from from the perspective of a linguist with some computational knowledge.
What is what is currently possible is actually two options which are a bit flawed is to to access resource via a web interface or to download the entire data set.
Analytics.
Amplified with some of our own resources.
For example, if you have the corpus high ceiling, it's a.
It's a middle Dutch corpus from 13th century.
Well, we have it as a web interface and you can search for something using a part of speech and you get a list of results.
As you can see.
But it will be hard to combine it with other resources.

What you can do is you can also download the whole data set so you get it as an XML in this case or a suggestion, but so you will have to write the whole script to combine it with other datasets or to do some more complex processing.
So we are aiming at people who want to have some more advanced functionality than a normal web interface, but who don't want to write a whole elaborate script and that's.
Why we why we want and why we don't want to develop something new?
If you look at from a conceptual point of view, if you look at changing search, this fits into a.
Better hierarchy and it's also fits into Dutch project Claria, which is the the dashboard counterpart of Clarendon Digital research infrastructure for Arts and Humanities.

And in this project there so there are few levels of search ability, so you have local search where you search into one resource or sting of Federated Search where you with one command to search into multiple resources.
But still the same kind and then changing search where they can be different types of resources and you can chain together also after each others.
So you have a sequential workflow.

So we're looking at this chaining search and what we can do what we came up with this career change search, which is a Python library and a Jupiter web interface to easily combine the expiration expiration of linguistic resources published in the clever in Korea.
Infrastructure such as corpora, lexica entry banks.
Well, how do we get there?
An early idea was because a lot of data is in a linked open data format.
And can we query for Sparkle query so an idea would be that you have a really big barkeri where you were you.
In this query you combine multiple resources, so you ask for multiple resources and you get results back for all those resources combined.
But The thing is that not all research are available is linked open data somewhere in another format.
So you could convert them.
Linked open data wouldn't always be the most natural format for some types of data.
For example for corpus data.
And The thing is that query becomes highly complex, so you're part of a query of a lexicon we're working on and this is only a small part of the query and it becomes very long.
A very complex, so this is not very user friendly.
So.
What we choose an implementation is that we we thought OK, uh spark, a query becomes very complex.
Why don't people just code if we make it easy for them to code, so we assume some knowledge of Python.

So we wrote a Python library and as a main data structure we do pandas dataframes which is a table like structure to store data and we extended it a lot of own functions divided into 4 modules with the search process, UI and utils module.
And to make it more interactive for people to have a kind of interface, we also admitted with Jupiter notebooks, which is a notebook you can you can use to run Python code in your browser.

So we create the notebook with a lot of examples which official will show few here in this presentation we create a sandbox where you can start coding yourself and we create a case study which I will show in this presentation.
We include the number of resources in this in this system, so we have support for Corporal Lexicon Treebanks.
We included a few, but default and more can be added using configuration file.
We include corpora which support the Clarion Federated Content search protocol.
We support the Black Lab corpus search engine which is used for a lot of internal UN corpora at the Dutch language institutes.
We support lexical via Spark queries and we an internal formats and we support the SGN andaloussi treebanks which can be queried via X path.
To give a view of the library, I go over it quickly, but we have a module to search, so you just have to type this.

You have to say I create the lexicon or created corpus an you give this name of the corpus which is defined in the configuration file where, where, where it can be found and then you just give a lemma or you give a pattern and a regex pattern.
Or you can give a word form and you can look for this listing and you will get a variable back with results.
And this results variable can be converted to a table like structure with the keywords in context, at least for a corpus.

And you will get back a table structure and this table structure gives the possibility if you have such a table structure for the corpus results and for example the lexical results to filter them and to combine them together.
That becomes really easy because we use these pandas dataframes.
Then we have the Utils module, which has some general operations, more low level operations on those data frames.
For example to compute the difference between two columns.
This can be easy if you have one resource, another resource, and you want to see what is the difference between them.
We
The process module, which has more complex linguistic processing, for example, extracting a lexicon from a list of corpus results.
And we have UI, a library with just a lot of stuff to show to show things in the Jupiter notebook.
The user in the browser and to save and load data frames to CSV files.
We show a small example.
This is something that has been done before, but others, but we show how this can be done, which chaining search.
This isn't a bit of Dutch linguistics is about.
If you have an adjective which would normally end with E, But then if you use a determiner une.
So in English you will.
The will be lost.
And we do this.
We investigate for which for which adjectives this could happen, and we were first getting some searching for some corpus results.
So we search in a modern Dutch corpus and we search for words which can be combined with an adjectives and adjectives.
They should not have an E at the end.
Then we search in Lexicon and we look for words with nothing E at the end in their lemma, but which do have an E in the word form.
And then we taken.

The section of the two, so this goes a bit bit fast, but you can look later to slice if you want to look at this precisely, but the idea is that in the lexicon we look at the forms which which should have this E actually, but then the corpus we see it doesn't have this E and we take this intersection and then we precisely get a table of the corpus examples where this is lacking, where it should have been actually.
Well, in a Jupiter notebook, this is how it looks.
So I looked at the library, but this is how it looks in a notebook.
So this is how you could look into browser.
So you arrive some codes, you click play and you get a results table back, and so this is how this could look.
We did a small case study, this actually some new research to show what the capabilities of career changing search are.

We looked at the letters of loot corpus which is a corpus of 17th and 18th century letters from Dutch sailors, which are annotated with a lot of metadata about the descenders and receivers of the data.
And what we want to look for is which vocabulary which words are specific for certain social Class A certain gender and a certain time periods.
So the steps we used claria chaining search for is to retrieve the data from the corpus to filter this data, split it on the metadata.
Then compute relative frequencies of the words per category and computed differences to look which which words are very specific for a certain.
Or which version very specific for a certain gender.
And this is not changing in the sense that we use multiple resources.
We use one resource, but we really use some of the complex processing capabilities of Gloria chaining search.
So what we we saw here is that we split the corpus in 17th and 18th century.
We looked at high class and what you see here, we computed relative frequencies of the words and then we look for the most specific ones.
So the ones which ever highest ratio between the relative frequency in one part and relative frequency in the other parts.
For example here you see not so much difference between the kind of words that are used in the 17th and 18th century.
So there's a different words with genres.
Quite the same since 17th century housewife is very specific friend, man health goodnight and in the 18th century it's Lord.
It's a joke, it's year, but it seems quite the same category of words, but we see larger differ.
This we go through social class.
We compare low and high social class in the 17th century.
Would we see now that the word specific for local loss are more words which are more in the personal swear?
It's goodnight is hard man.
Letter Lord.
While the high class is more talking about business topics, there not talking about Captain Mushu, they're looking about sugar.
So maybe selling some sugar about pounds, about Bill, so it's more and more business topics in the higher class.
We see a kind of the same same contrast if you look between male and female.
So it seems that so we look just as 17th century, just at low class and then you see that for mill you have a lot more business topics and you have more personal topics for female.
And in the higher class.
There's also.
This contrast, but it's a. I think it's.
A bit less pronounced, but you if you see the same you see the same contrast here actually.
So she sugar for Milan you see man and child and letter and son and good night for a female.
So what this case study actually shows that you can, so we cannot really draw definite conclusions.
But yes, you can see some contrast in vocabulary across different social linguistic variables.
And actually just shows what the value of a career changing source could be that you can really facilitate and accelerate linguistic research.
Well, there are some points for discussion as well.
Still OK, we made it easier for people than writing whole on script.
But still some programming knowledge is needed.
Also, well, this is not to discuss another discussion point, but it's wise to use the library directly.
If you have a really long computation, you might not want to do that in your browser in a notebook.

And if you have very large datasets which are larger than your computer memory, so if your computer memories assisting 16 gigabyte which you have 30 gigabyte data sets, then this won't work at the moment.
So this is something that has to be further optimized.
We will still demonstrate this during the poster session, so you can see a bit more and you can also try it yourself on the GitHub repository.
You can download and install it on your computer, or you can run it in the cloud on Azure.
And the documentation can also be found online.
Thank you.
Question.
One of the things that I always wanted is the following.

I do a lot of searching in treebanks, which only have morphosyntactic and syntactic information and no semantic information, but sometimes I must know, for example, of a noun, whether it indicates a human or not.
An that information is not in the tree bank, so I have to get it from a different source and I could get it from semantic lexical.
For example word net or other lexicons that have this information.
So we'd like to look up for those words whether they indicate the human or not or are ambiguous.
Of course, most words in natural language ambiguous, so you have and then you can, let's say, use an external resource electrical in combination with the tree bank search to, let's say, classify.
Your results and I wonder, is that now possible with this method.
Yeah, that should be possible.
So what you do then?
It's bit maybe a little bit the same as what we saw here, so you first in this case that you first to corpus search.
Now in this case you first do tree Bank search so you get a number of results.
You get some parsed Anderson's back and then you look in the lexical man you look for.
I think it will.
It will be more like a sequential search or what you search in Lexicon will be based on your previous results, so you will have to fill in words here from your results and you will get back there.
The animacy of the word, or the semantic properties and you can then filter the results you got from the corpus.
You can filter them based on this lexicon results like you do here here.
Also, you do corpus results were filled it with lexical.
So this shooting Prince will be possible, yes.
Thank you for your presentation.

Anyway, it will be really hard to create a really user friendly web interface for this and then we can start.

The Sparkle query is even more complex and even more error prone to code.
So then we thought OK, Python programming.
Not everybody can can do this, but I think a lot of linguists at the moment are looking into this computational methods and are starting to code.

I think the issue solution.
